column2: CHAPTER IV.
column3: CHAPTER four.

column2: The food question.--Objections to paraffine oil as an atmosphere.--Advantages of cheese as a travelling companion.--A married woman deserts her home.--Further provision for getting upset.--I pack.--Cussedness of tooth-brushes.--George and Harris pack.--Awful behaviour of Montmorency.--We retire to rest.
column3: The food question.--Objections to paraffine oil as an atmosphere.--Advantages of cheese as a travelling companion.--A married woman deserts her home.--Further provision for getting upset.--I pack.--Cussedness of tooth brushes.--George and Harris pack.--Awful behaviour of Montmorency.--We retire to rest.

column2: Then we discussed the food question.
column3: Then we discussed the food question.

column2: George said:
column3: George said:

column2: Begin with breakfast. (George is so practical.) "Now for breakfast we shall want a frying-pan"--(Harris said it was indigestible; but we merely urged him not to be an ass, and George went on)--"a tea-pot and a kettle, and a methylated spirit stove."
column3: Begin with breakfast. (George is so practical.) "Now for breakfast we shall want a frying pan"--(Harris said it was indigestible; but we merely urged him not to be an ass, and George went on)--"a tea pot and a kettle, and a methylated spirit stove."

column2: No oil, said George, with a significant look; and Harris and I agreed.
column3: No oil, said George, with a significant look; and Harris and I agreed.

column2: We had taken up an oil-stove once, but "never again." It had been like living in an oil-shop that week.
column3: We had taken up an oil stove once, but "never again." It had been like living in an oil shop that week.

column2: It oozed.
column3: It oozed.

column2: I never saw such a thing as paraffine oil is to ooze.
column3: I never saw such a thing as paraffine oil is to ooze.

column2: We kept it in the nose of the boat, and, from there, it oozed down to the rudder, impregnating the whole boat and everything in it on its way, and it oozed over the river, and saturated the scenery and spoilt the atmosphere.
column3: We kept it in the nose of the boat, and, from there, it oozed down to the rudder, impregnating the whole boat and everything in it on its way, and it oozed over the river, and saturated the scenery and spoilt the atmosphere.

column2: Sometimes a westerly oily wind blew, and at other times an easterly oily wind, and sometimes it blew a northerly oily wind, and maybe a southerly oily wind; but whether it came from the Arctic snows, or was raised in the waste of the desert sands, it came alike to us laden with the fragrance of paraffine oil.
column3: Sometimes a westerly oily wind blew, and at other times an easterly oily wind, and sometimes it blew a northerly oily wind, and maybe a southerly oily wind; but whether it came from the Arctic snows, or was raised in the waste of the desert sands, it came alike to us laden with the fragrance of paraffine oil.

column2: And that oil oozed up and ruined the sunset; and as for the moonbeams, they positively reeked of paraffine.
column3: And that oil oozed up and ruined the sunset; and as for the moonbeams, they positively reeked of paraffine.

column2: We tried to get away from it at Marlow.
column3: We tried to get away from it at Marlow.

column2: We left the boat by the bridge, and took a walk through the town to escape it, but it followed us.
column3: We left the boat by the bridge, and took a walk through the town to escape it, but it followed us.

column2: The whole town was full of oil.
column3: The whole town was full of oil.

column2: We passed through the church-yard, and it seemed as if the people had been buried in oil.
column3: We passed through the church yard, and it seemed as if the people had been buried in oil.

column2: The High Street stunk of oil; we wondered how people could live in it.
column3: The High Street stunk of oil; we wondered how people could live in it.

column2: And we walked miles upon miles out Birmingham way; but it was no use, the country was steeped in oil.
column3: And we walked miles upon miles out Birmingham way; but it was no use, the country was steeped in oil.

column2: At the end of that trip we met together at midnight in a lonely field, under a blasted oak, and took an awful oath (we had been swearing for a whole week about the thing in an ordinary, middle-class way, but this was a swell affair)--an awful oath never to take paraffine oil with us in a boat again-except, of course, in case of sickness.
column3: At the end of that trip we met together at midnight in a lonely field, under a blasted oak, and took an awful oath (we had been swearing for a whole week about the thing in an ordinary, middle class way, but this was a swell affair)--an awful oath never to take paraffine oil with us in a boat again except, of course, in case of sickness.

column2: Therefore, in the present instance, we confined ourselves to methylated spirit.
column3: Therefore, in the present instance, we confined ourselves to methylated spirit.

column2: Even that is bad enough.
column3: Even that is bad enough.

column2: You get methylated pie and methylated cake.
column3: You get methylated pie and methylated cake.

column2: But methylated spirit is more wholesome when taken into the system in large quantities than paraffine oil.
column3: But methylated spirit is more wholesome when taken into the system in large quantities than paraffine oil.

column2: For other breakfast things, George suggested eggs and bacon, which were easy to cook, cold meat, tea, bread and butter, and jam.
column3: For other breakfast things, George suggested eggs and bacon, which were easy to cook, cold meat, tea, bread and butter, and jam.

column2: For lunch, he said, we could have biscuits, cold meat, bread and butter, and jam--but _no cheese_.
column3: For lunch, he said, we could have biscuits, cold meat, bread and butter, and jam-but underscore no cheese underscore.

column2: Cheese, like oil, makes too much of itself.
column3: Cheese, like oil, makes too much of itself.

column2: It wants the whole boat to itself.
column3: It wants the whole boat to itself.

column2: It goes through the hamper, and gives a cheesy flavour to everything else there.
column3: It goes through the hamper, and gives a cheesy flavour to everything else there.

column2: You can't tell whether you are eating apple-pie or German sausage, or strawberries and cream.
column3: You can't tell whether you are eating apple pie or German sausage, or strawberries and cream.

column2: It all seems cheese.
column3: It all seems cheese.

column2: There is too much odour about cheese.
column3: There is too much odour about cheese.

column2: I remember a friend of mine, buying a couple of cheeses at Liverpool. Splendid cheeses they were, ripe and mellow, and with a two hundred horse-power scent about them that might have been warranted to carry three miles, and knock a man over at two hundred yards.
column3: I remember a friend of mine, buying a couple of cheeses at Liverpool. Splendid cheeses they were, ripe and mellow, and with a two hundred horse power scent about them that might have been warranted to carry three miles, and knock a man over at two hundred yards.

column2: I was in Liverpool at the time, and my friend said that if I didn't mind he would get me to take them back with me to London, as he should not be coming up for a day or two himself, and he did not think the cheeses ought to be kept much longer.
column3: I was in Liverpool at the time, and my friend said that if I didn't mind he would get me to take them back with me to London, as he should not be coming up for a day or two himself, and he did not think the cheeses ought to be kept much longer.

column2: Oh, with pleasure, dear boy, I replied, "with pleasure."
column3: Oh, with pleasure, dear boy, I replied, "with pleasure."

column2: I called for the cheeses, and took them away in a cab.
column3: I called for the cheeses, and took them away in a cab.

column2: It was a ramshackle affair, dragged along by a knock-kneed, broken-winded somnambulist, which his owner, in a moment of enthusiasm, during conversation, referred to as a horse.
column3: It was a ramshackle affair, dragged along by a knock kneed, broken winded somnambulist, which his owner, in a moment of enthusiasm, during conversation, referred to as a horse.

column2: I put the cheeses on the top, and we started off at a shamble that would have done credit to the swiftest steam-roller ever built, and all went merry as a funeral bell, until we turned the corner.
column3: I put the cheeses on the top, and we started off at a shamble that would have done credit to the swiftest steam roller ever built, and all went merry as a funeral bell, until we turned the corner.

column2: There, the wind carried a whiff from the cheeses full on to our steed.
column3: There, the wind carried a whiff from the cheeses full on to our steed.

column2: It woke him up, and, with a snort of terror, he dashed off at three miles an hour.
column3: It woke him up, and, with a snort of terror, he dashed off at three miles an hour.

column2: The wind still blew in his direction, and before we reached the end of the street he was laying himself out at the rate of nearly four miles an hour, leaving the cripples and stout old ladies simply nowhere.
column3: The wind still blew in his direction, and before we reached the end of the street he was laying himself out at the rate of nearly four miles an hour, leaving the cripples and stout old ladies simply nowhere.

column2: It took two porters as well as the driver to hold him in at the station; and I do not think they would have done it, even then, had not one of the men had the presence of mind to put a handkerchief over his nose, and to light a bit of brown paper.
column3: It took two porters as well as the driver to hold him in at the station; and I do not think they would have done it, even then, had not one of the men had the presence of mind to put a handkerchief over his nose, and to light a bit of brown paper.

column2: I took my ticket, and marched proudly up the platform, with my cheeses, the people falling back respectfully on either side.
column3: I took my ticket, and marched proudly up the platform, with my cheeses, the people falling back respectfully on either side.

column2: The train was crowded, and I had to get into a carriage where there were already seven other people.
column3: The train was crowded, and I had to get into a carriage where there were already seven other people.

column2: One crusty old gentleman objected, but I got in, notwithstanding; and, putting my cheeses upon the rack, squeezed down with a pleasant smile, and said it was a warm day.
column3: One crusty old gentleman objected, but I got in, notwithstanding; and, putting my cheeses upon the rack, squeezed down with a pleasant smile, and said it was a warm day.

column2: A few moments passed, and then the old gentleman began to fidget.
column3: A few moments passed, and then the old gentleman began to fidget.

column2: Very close in here, he said.
column3: Very close in here, he said.

column2: Quite oppressive, said the man next him.
column3: Quite oppressive, said the man next him.

column2: And then they both began sniffing, and, at the third sniff, they caught it right on the chest, and rose up without another word and went out. And then a stout lady got up, and said it was disgraceful that a respectable married woman should be harried about in this way, and gathered up a bag and eight parcels and went.
column3: And then they both began sniffing, and, at the third sniff, they caught it right on the chest, and rose up without another word and went out. And then a stout lady got up, and said it was disgraceful that a respectable married woman should be harried about in this way, and gathered up a bag and eight parcels and went.

column2: The remaining four passengers sat on for a while, until a solemn-looking man in the corner, who, from his dress and general appearance, seemed to belong to the undertaker class, said it put him in mind of dead baby; and the other three passengers tried to get out of the door at the same time, and hurt themselves.
column3: The remaining four passengers sat on for a while, until a solemn looking man in the corner, who, from his dress and general appearance, seemed to belong to the undertaker class, said it put him in mind of dead baby; and the other three passengers tried to get out of the door at the same time, and hurt themselves.

column2: [Picture: Railway carriage]
column3: [Picture: Railway carriage]

column2: I smiled at the black gentleman, and said I thought we were going to have the carriage to ourselves; and he laughed pleasantly, and said that some people made such a fuss over a little thing.
column3: I smiled at the black gentleman, and said I thought we were going to have the carriage to ourselves; and he laughed pleasantly, and said that some people made such a fuss over a little thing.

column2: But even he grew strangely depressed after we had started, and so, when we reached Crewe, I asked him to come and have a drink.
column3: But even he grew strangely depressed after we had started, and so, when we reached Crewe, I asked him to come and have a drink.

column2: He accepted, and we forced our way into the buffet, where we yelled, and stamped, and waved our umbrellas for a quarter of an hour; and then a young lady came, and asked us if we wanted anything.
column3: He accepted, and we forced our way into the buffet, where we yelled, and stamped, and waved our umbrellas for a quarter of an hour; and then a young lady came, and asked us if we wanted anything.

column2: What's yours? I said, turning to my friend.
column3: What's yours? I said, turning to my friend.

column2: I'll have half-a-crown's worth of brandy, neat, if you please, miss, he responded.
column3: I'll have half a crown's worth of brandy, neat, if you please, miss, he responded.

column2: And he went off quietly after he had drunk it and got into another carriage, which I thought mean.
column3: And he went off quietly after he had drunk it and got into another carriage, which I thought mean.

column2: From Crewe I had the compartment to myself, though the train was crowded. As we drew up at the different stations, the people, seeing my empty carriage, would rush for it.
column3: From Crewe I had the compartment to myself, though the train was crowded. As we drew up at the different stations, the people, seeing my empty carriage, would rush for it.

column2: Here y' are, Maria; come along, plenty of room. "All right, Tom; we'll get in here," they would shout.
column3: Here y' are, Maria; come along, plenty of room. "All right, Tom; we'll get in here," they would shout.

column2: And they would run along, carrying heavy bags, and fight round the door to get in first.
column3: And they would run along, carrying heavy bags, and fight round the door to get in first.

column2: And one would open the door and mount the steps, and stagger back into the arms of the man behind him; and they would all come and have a sniff, and then droop off and squeeze into other carriages, or pay the difference and go first.
column3: And one would open the door and mount the steps, and stagger back into the arms of the man behind him; and they would all come and have a sniff, and then droop off and squeeze into other carriages, or pay the difference and go first.

column2: From Euston, I took the cheeses down to my friend's house.
column3: From Euston, I took the cheeses down to my friend's house.

column2: When his wife came into the room she smelt round for an instant.
column3: When his wife came into the room she smelt round for an instant.

column2: Then she said:
column3: Then she said:

column2: What is it?	What is it?
column3: true

column2: Tell me the worst."
column3: Tell me the worst."

column2: I said:
column3: I said:

column2: It's cheeses.	It's cheeses.
column3: true

column2: Tom bought them in Liverpool, and asked me to bring them up with me."
column3: Tom bought them in Liverpool, and asked me to bring them up with me."

column2: And I added that I hoped she understood that it had nothing to do with me; and she said that she was sure of that, but that she would speak to Tom about it when he came back.
column3: And I added that I hoped she understood that it had nothing to do with me; and she said that she was sure of that, but that she would speak to Tom about it when he came back.

column2: My friend was detained in Liverpool longer than he expected; and, three days later, as he hadn't returned home, his wife called on me.
column3: My friend was detained in Liverpool longer than he expected; and, three days later, as he hadn't returned home, his wife called on me.

column2: She said:
column3: She said:

column2: What did Tom say about those cheeses?
column3: What did Tom say about those cheeses?

column2: I replied that he had directed they were to be kept in a moist place, and that nobody was to touch them.
column3: I replied that he had directed they were to be kept in a moist place, and that nobody was to touch them.

column2: She said:
column3: She said:

column2: Nobody's likely to touch them.	Nobody's likely to touch them.
column3: true

column2: Had he smelt them?"
column3: Had he smelt them?"

column2: I thought he had, and added that he seemed greatly attached to them.
column3: I thought he had, and added that he seemed greatly attached to them.

column2: You think he would be upset, she queried, "if I gave a man a sovereign to take them away and bury them?"
column3: You think he would be upset, she queried, "if I gave a man a sovereign to take them away and bury them?"

column2: I answered that I thought he would never smile again.
column3: I answered that I thought he would never smile again.

column2: An idea struck her.
column3: An idea struck her.

column2: She said:
column3: She said:

column2: Do you mind keeping them for him?	Do you mind keeping them for him?
column3: true

column2: Let me send them round to you."
column3: Let me send them round to you."

column2: Madam, I replied, "for myself I like the smell of cheese, and the journey the other day with them from Liverpool I shall ever look back upon as a happy ending to a pleasant holiday.
column3: Madam, I replied, "for myself I like the smell of cheese, and the journey the other day with them from Liverpool I shall ever look back upon as a happy ending to a pleasant holiday.

column2: But, in this world, we must consider others.
column3: But, in this world, we must consider others.

column2: The lady under whose roof I have the honour of residing is a widow, and, for all I know, possibly an orphan too.
column3: The lady under whose roof I have the honour of residing is a widow, and, for all I know, possibly an orphan too.

column2: She has a strong, I may say an eloquent, objection to being what she terms 'put upon.' The presence of your husband's cheeses in her house she would, I instinctively feel, regard as a 'put upon'; and it shall never be said that I put upon the widow and the orphan."
column3: She has a strong, I may say an eloquent, objection to being what she terms 'put upon.' The presence of your husband's cheeses in her house she would, I instinctively feel, regard as a 'put upon'; and it shall never be said that I put upon the widow and the orphan."

column2: Very well, then, said my friend's wife, rising, "all I have to say is, that I shall take the children and go to an hotel until those cheeses are eaten.
column3: Very well, then, said my friend's wife, rising, "all I have to say is, that I shall take the children and go to an hotel until those cheeses are eaten.

column2: I decline to live any longer in the same house with them."
column3: I decline to live any longer in the same house with them."

column2: She kept her word, leaving the place in charge of the charwoman, who, when asked if she could stand the smell, replied, "What smell?" and who, when taken close to the cheeses and told to sniff hard, said she could detect a faint odour of melons.
column3: She kept her word, leaving the place in charge of the charwoman, who, when asked if she could stand the smell, replied, "What smell?" and who, when taken close to the cheeses and told to sniff hard, said she could detect a faint odour of melons.

column2: It was argued from this that little injury could result to the woman from the atmosphere, and she was left.
column3: It was argued from this that little injury could result to the woman from the atmosphere, and she was left.

column2: The hotel bill came to fifteen guineas; and my friend, after reckoning everything up, found that the cheeses had cost him eight-and-sixpence a pound.
column3: The hotel bill came to fifteen guineas; and my friend, after reckoning everything up, found that the cheeses had cost him eight and sixpence a pound.

column2: He said he dearly loved a bit of cheese, but it was beyond his means; so he determined to get rid of them.
column3: He said he dearly loved a bit of cheese, but it was beyond his means; so he determined to get rid of them.

column2: He threw them into the canal; but had to fish them out again, as the bargemen complained.
column3: He threw them into the canal; but had to fish them out again, as the bargemen complained.

column2: They said it made them feel quite faint.
column3: They said it made them feel quite faint.

column2: And, after that, he took them one dark night and left them in the parish mortuary.
column3: And, after that, he took them one dark night and left them in the parish mortuary.

column2: But the coroner discovered them, and made a fearful fuss.
column3: But the coroner discovered them, and made a fearful fuss.

column2: He said it was a plot to deprive him of his living by waking up the corpses.
column3: He said it was a plot to deprive him of his living by waking up the corpses.

column2: My friend got rid of them, at last, by taking them down to a sea-side town, and burying them on the beach.
column3: My friend got rid of them, at last, by taking them down to a sea side town, and burying them on the beach.

column2: It gained the place quite a reputation.
column3: It gained the place quite a reputation.

column2: Visitors said they had never noticed before how strong the air was, and weak-chested and consumptive people used to throng there for years afterwards.
column3: Visitors said they had never noticed before how strong the air was, and weak chested and consumptive people used to throng there for years afterwards.

column2: Fond as I am of cheese, therefore, I hold that George was right in declining to take any.
column3: Fond as I am of cheese, therefore, I hold that George was right in declining to take any.

column2: We shan't want any tea, said George (Harris's face fell at this); "but we'll have a good round, square, slap-up meal at seven--dinner, tea, and supper combined."
column3: We shan't want any tea, said George (Harris's face fell at this); "but we'll have a good round, square, slap up meal at seven-dinner, tea, and supper combined."

column2: Harris grew more cheerful.
column3: Harris grew more cheerful.

column2: George suggested meat and fruit pies, cold meat, tomatoes, fruit, and green stuff.
column3: George suggested meat and fruit pies, cold meat, tomatoes, fruit, and green stuff.

column2: For drink, we took some wonderful sticky concoction of Harris's, which you mixed with water and called lemonade, plenty of tea, and a bottle of whisky, in case, as George said, we got upset.
column3: For drink, we took some wonderful sticky concoction of Harris's, which you mixed with water and called lemonade, plenty of tea, and a bottle of whisky, in case, as George said, we got upset.

column2: It seemed to me that George harped too much on the getting-upset idea. It seemed to me the wrong spirit to go about the trip in.
column3: It seemed to me that George harped too much on the getting upset idea. It seemed to me the wrong spirit to go about the trip in.

column2: But I'm glad we took the whisky.
column3: But I'm glad we took the whisky.

column2: We didn't take beer or wine.
column3: We didn't take beer or wine.

column2: They are a mistake up the river.
column3: They are a mistake up the river.

column2: They make you feel sleepy and heavy.
column3: They make you feel sleepy and heavy.

column2: A glass in the evening when you are doing a mouch round the town and looking at the girls is all right enough; but don't drink when the sun is blazing down on your head, and you've got hard work to do.
column3: A glass in the evening when you are doing a mouch round the town and looking at the girls is all right enough; but don't drink when the sun is blazing down on your head, and you've got hard work to do.

column2: We made a list of the things to be taken, and a pretty lengthy one it was, before we parted that evening.
column3: We made a list of the things to be taken, and a pretty lengthy one it was, before we parted that evening.

column2: The next day, which was Friday, we got them all together, and met in the evening to pack.
column3: The next day, which was Friday, we got them all together, and met in the evening to pack.

column2: We got a big Gladstone for the clothes, and a couple of hampers for the victuals and the cooking utensils.
column3: We got a big Gladstone for the clothes, and a couple of hampers for the victuals and the cooking utensils.

column2: We moved the table up against the window, piled everything in a heap in the middle of the floor, and sat round and looked at it.
column3: We moved the table up against the window, piled everything in a heap in the middle of the floor, and sat round and looked at it.

column2: I said I'd pack.
column3: I said I'd pack.

column2: I rather pride myself on my packing.
column3: I rather pride myself on my packing.

column2: Packing is one of those many things that I feel I know more about than any other person living. (It surprises me myself, sometimes, how many of these subjects there are.) I impressed the fact upon George and Harris, and told them that they had better leave the whole matter entirely to me.
column3: Packing is one of those many things that I feel I know more about than any other person living. (It surprises me myself, sometimes, how many of these subjects there are.) I impressed the fact upon George and Harris, and told them that they had better leave the whole matter entirely to me.

column2: They fell into the suggestion with a readiness that had something uncanny about it.
column3: They fell into the suggestion with a readiness that had something uncanny about it.

column2: George put on a pipe and spread himself over the easy-chair, and Harris cocked his legs on the table and lit a cigar.
column3: George put on a pipe and spread himself over the easy chair, and Harris cocked his legs on the table and lit a cigar.

column2: This was hardly what I intended.
column3: This was hardly what I intended.

column2: What I had meant, of course, was, that I should boss the job, and that Harris and George should potter about under my directions, I pushing them aside every now and then with, "Oh, you--!" "Here, let me do it." "There you are, simple enough!"--really teaching them, as you might say.
column3: What I had meant, of course, was, that I should boss the job, and that Harris and George should potter about under my directions, I pushing them aside every now and then with, "Oh, you-!" "Here, let me do it." "There you are, simple enough!"--really teaching them, as you might say.

column2: Their taking it in the way they did irritated me.
column3: Their taking it in the way they did irritated me.

column2: There is nothing does irritate me more than seeing other people sitting about doing nothing when I'm working.
column3: There is nothing does irritate me more than seeing other people sitting about doing nothing when I'm working.

column2: I lived with a man once who used to make me mad that way.
column3: I lived with a man once who used to make me mad that way.

column2: He would loll on the sofa and watch me doing things by the hour together, following me round the room with his eyes, wherever I went.
column3: He would loll on the sofa and watch me doing things by the hour together, following me round the room with his eyes, wherever I went.

column2: He said it did him real good to look on at me, messing about.
column3: He said it did him real good to look on at me, messing about.

column2: He said it made him feel that life was not an idle dream to be gaped and yawned through, but a noble task, full of duty and stern work.
column3: He said it made him feel that life was not an idle dream to be gaped and yawned through, but a noble task, full of duty and stern work.

column2: He said he often wondered now how he could have gone on before he met me, never having anybody to look at while they worked.
column3: He said he often wondered now how he could have gone on before he met me, never having anybody to look at while they worked.

column2: Now, I'm not like that.
column3: Now, I'm not like that.

column2: I can't sit still and see another man slaving and working.
column3: I can't sit still and see another man slaving and working.

column2: I want to get up and superintend, and walk round with my hands in my pockets, and tell him what to do.
column3: I want to get up and superintend, and walk round with my hands in my pockets, and tell him what to do.

column2: It is my energetic nature. I can't help it.
column3: It is my energetic nature. I can't help it.

column2: However, I did not say anything, but started the packing.
column3: However, I did not say anything, but started the packing.

column2: It seemed a longer job than I had thought it was going to be; but I got the bag finished at last, and I sat on it and strapped it.
column3: It seemed a longer job than I had thought it was going to be; but I got the bag finished at last, and I sat on it and strapped it.

column2: Ain't you going to put the boots in? said Harris.
column3: Ain't you going to put the boots in? said Harris.

column2: And I looked round, and found I had forgotten them.
column3: And I looked round, and found I had forgotten them.

column2: That's just like Harris.
column3: That's just like Harris.

column2: He couldn't have said a word until I'd got the bag shut and strapped, of course.
column3: He couldn't have said a word until I'd got the bag shut and strapped, of course.

column2: And George laughed--one of those irritating, senseless, chuckle-headed, crack-jawed laughs of his.
column3: And George laughed-one of those irritating, senseless, chuckle headed, crack jawed laughs of his.

column2: They do make me so wild.
column3: They do make me so wild.

column2: I opened the bag and packed the boots in; and then, just as I was going to close it, a horrible idea occurred to me.
column3: I opened the bag and packed the boots in; and then, just as I was going to close it, a horrible idea occurred to me.

column2: Had I packed my tooth-brush?
column3: Had I packed my tooth brush?

column2: I don't know how it is, but I never do know whether I've packed my tooth-brush.
column3: I don't know how it is, but I never do know whether I've packed my tooth brush.

column2: My tooth-brush is a thing that haunts me when I'm travelling, and makes my life a misery.
column3: My tooth brush is a thing that haunts me when I'm travelling, and makes my life a misery.

column2: I dream that I haven't packed it, and wake up in a cold perspiration, and get out of bed and hunt for it.
column3: I dream that I haven't packed it, and wake up in a cold perspiration, and get out of bed and hunt for it.

column2: And, in the morning, I pack it before I have used it, and have to unpack again to get it, and it is always the last thing I turn out of the bag; and then I repack and forget it, and have to rush upstairs for it at the last moment and carry it to the railway station, wrapped up in my pocket-handkerchief.
column3: And, in the morning, I pack it before I have used it, and have to unpack again to get it, and it is always the last thing I turn out of the bag; and then I repack and forget it, and have to rush upstairs for it at the last moment and carry it to the railway station, wrapped up in my pocket handkerchief.

column2: [Picture: Boot] Of course I had to turn every mortal thing out now, and, of course, I could not find it.
column3: [Picture: Boot] Of course I had to turn every mortal thing out now, and, of course, I could not find it.

column2: I rummaged the things up into much the same state that they must have been before the world was created, and when chaos reigned.
column3: I rummaged the things up into much the same state that they must have been before the world was created, and when chaos reigned.

column2: Of course, I found George's and Harris's eighteen times over, but I couldn't find my own.
column3: Of course, I found George's and Harris's eighteen times over, but I couldn't find my own.

column2: I put the things back one by one, and held everything up and shook it.
column3: I put the things back one by one, and held everything up and shook it.

column2: Then I found it inside a boot. I repacked once more.
column3: Then I found it inside a boot. I repacked once more.

column2: When I had finished, George asked if the soap was in.
column3: When I had finished, George asked if the soap was in.

column2: I said I didn't care a hang whether the soap was in or whether it wasn't; and I slammed the bag to and strapped it, and found that I had packed my tobacco-pouch in it, and had to re-open it.
column3: I said I didn't care a hang whether the soap was in or whether it wasn't; and I slammed the bag to and strapped it, and found that I had packed my tobacco pouch in it, and had to re-open it.

column2: It got shut up finally at 10.5 p.m., and then there remained the hampers to do.
column3: It got shut up finally at ten.five p m, and then there remained the hampers to do.

column2: Harris said that we should be wanting to start in less than twelve hours' time, and thought that he and George had better do the rest; and I agreed and sat down, and they had a go.
column3: Harris said that we should be wanting to start in less than twelve hours' time, and thought that he and George had better do the rest; and I agreed and sat down, and they had a go.

column2: They began in a light-hearted spirit, evidently intending to show me how to do it.
column3: They began in a light-hearted spirit, evidently intending to show me how to do it.

column2: I made no comment; I only waited.
column3: I made no comment; I only waited.

column2: When George is hanged, Harris will be the worst packer in this world; and I looked at the piles of plates and cups, and kettles, and bottles and jars, and pies, and stoves, and cakes, and tomatoes, &c., and felt that the thing would soon become exciting.
column3: When George is hanged, Harris will be the worst packer in this world; and I looked at the piles of plates and cups, and kettles, and bottles and jars, and pies, and stoves, and cakes, and tomatoes, and c., and felt that the thing would soon become exciting.

column2: It did.
column3: It did.

column2: They started with breaking a cup.
column3: They started with breaking a cup.

column2: That was the first thing they did.
column3: That was the first thing they did.

column2: They did that just to show you what they _could_ do, and to get you interested.
column3: They did that just to show you what they underscore could underscore do, and to get you interested.

column2: Then Harris packed the strawberry jam on top of a tomato and squashed it, and they had to pick out the tomato with a teaspoon.
column3: Then Harris packed the strawberry jam on top of a tomato and squashed it, and they had to pick out the tomato with a teaspoon.

column2: And then it was George's turn, and he trod on the butter.
column3: And then it was George's turn, and he trod on the butter.

column2: I didn't say anything, but I came over and sat on the edge of the table and watched them.
column3: I didn't say anything, but I came over and sat on the edge of the table and watched them.

column2: It irritated them more than anything I could have said.
column3: It irritated them more than anything I could have said.

column2: I felt that.
column3: I felt that.

column2: It made them nervous and excited, and they stepped on things, and put things behind them, and then couldn't find them when they wanted them; and they packed the pies at the bottom, and put heavy things on top, and smashed the pies in.
column3: It made them nervous and excited, and they stepped on things, and put things behind them, and then couldn't find them when they wanted them; and they packed the pies at the bottom, and put heavy things on top, and smashed the pies in.

column2: They upset salt over everything, and as for the butter!
column3: They upset salt over everything, and as for the butter!

column2: I never saw two men do more with one-and-twopence worth of butter in my whole life than they did.
column3: I never saw two men do more with one and twopence worth of butter in my whole life than they did.

column2: After George had got it off his slipper, they tried to put it in the kettle.
column3: After George had got it off his slipper, they tried to put it in the kettle.

column2: It wouldn't go in, and what _was_ in wouldn't come out. They did scrape it out at last, and put it down on a chair, and Harris sat on it, and it stuck to him, and they went looking for it all over the room.
column3: It wouldn't go in, and what underscore was underscore in wouldn't come out. They did scrape it out at last, and put it down on a chair, and Harris sat on it, and it stuck to him, and they went looking for it all over the room.

column2: I'll take my oath I put it down on that chair, said George, staring at the empty seat.
column3: I'll take my oath I put it down on that chair, said George, staring at the empty seat.

column2: I saw you do it myself, not a minute ago, said Harris.
column3: I saw you do it myself, not a minute ago, said Harris.

column2: Then they started round the room again looking for it; and then they met again in the centre, and stared at one another.
column3: Then they started round the room again looking for it; and then they met again in the centre, and stared at one another.

column2: Most extraordinary thing I ever heard of, said George.
column3: Most extraordinary thing I ever heard of, said George.

column2: So mysterious! said Harris.
column3: So mysterious! said Harris.

column2: Then George got round at the back of Harris and saw it.
column3: Then George got round at the back of Harris and saw it.

column2: Why, here it is all the time, he exclaimed, indignantly.
column3: Why, here it is all the time, he exclaimed, indignantly.

column2: Where? cried Harris, spinning round.
column3: Where? cried Harris, spinning round.

column2: Stand still, can't you! roared George, flying after him.
column3: Stand still, can't you! roared George, flying after him.

column2: And they got it off, and packed it in the teapot.
column3: And they got it off, and packed it in the teapot.

column2: Montmorency was in it all, of course.
column3: Montmorency was in it all, of course.

column2: Montmorency's ambition in life, is to get in the way and be sworn at.
column3: Montmorency's ambition in life, is to get in the way and be sworn at.

column2: If he can squirm in anywhere where he particularly is not wanted, and be a perfect nuisance, and make people mad, and have things thrown at his head, then he feels his day has not been wasted.
column3: If he can squirm in anywhere where he particularly is not wanted, and be a perfect nuisance, and make people mad, and have things thrown at his head, then he feels his day has not been wasted.

column2: To get somebody to stumble over him, and curse him steadily for an hour, is his highest aim and object; and, when he has succeeded in accomplishing this, his conceit becomes quite unbearable.
column3: To get somebody to stumble over him, and curse him steadily for an hour, is his highest aim and object; and, when he has succeeded in accomplishing this, his conceit becomes quite unbearable.

column2: He came and sat down on things, just when they were wanted to be packed; and he laboured under the fixed belief that, whenever Harris or George reached out their hand for anything, it was his cold, damp nose that they wanted.
column3: He came and sat down on things, just when they were wanted to be packed; and he laboured under the fixed belief that, whenever Harris or George reached out their hand for anything, it was his cold, damp nose that they wanted.

column2: He put his leg into the jam, and he worried the teaspoons, and he pretended that the lemons were rats, and got into the hamper and killed three of them before Harris could land him with the frying-pan.
column3: He put his leg into the jam, and he worried the teaspoons, and he pretended that the lemons were rats, and got into the hamper and killed three of them before Harris could land him with the frying pan.

column2: Harris said I encouraged him.
column3: Harris said I encouraged him.

column2: I didn't encourage him.
column3: I didn't encourage him.

column2: A dog like that don't want any encouragement.
column3: A dog like that don't want any encouragement.

column2: It's the natural, original sin that is born in him that makes him do things like that.
column3: It's the natural, original sin that is born in him that makes him do things like that.

column2: The packing was done at 12.50; and Harris sat on the big hamper, and said he hoped nothing would be found broken.
column3: The packing was done at twelve point five zero; and Harris sat on the big hamper, and said he hoped nothing would be found broken.

column2: George said that if anything was broken it was broken, which reflection seemed to comfort him.
column3: George said that if anything was broken it was broken, which reflection seemed to comfort him.

column2: He also said he was ready for bed.
column3: He also said he was ready for bed.

column2: We were all ready for bed.
column3: We were all ready for bed.

column2: Harris was to sleep with us that night, and we went upstairs.
column3: Harris was to sleep with us that night, and we went upstairs.

column2: We tossed for beds, and Harris had to sleep with me.
column3: We tossed for beds, and Harris had to sleep with me.

column2: He said:
column3: He said:

column2: Do you prefer the inside or the outside, J.?
column3: Do you prefer the inside or the outside, j?

column2: I said I generally preferred to sleep _inside_ a bed.
column3: I said I generally preferred to sleep underscore inside underscore a bed.

column2: Harris said it was old.
column3: Harris said it was old.

column2: George said:
column3: George said:

column2: What time shall I wake you fellows?
column3: What time shall I wake you fellows?

column2: Harris said:
column3: Harris said:

column2: Seven.
column3: Seven.

column2: I said:
column3: I said:

column2: No--six, because I wanted to write some letters.
column3: No-six, because I wanted to write some letters.

column2: Harris and I had a bit of a row over it, but at last split the difference, and said half-past six.
column3: Harris and I had a bit of a row over it, but at last split the difference, and said half past six.

column2: Wake us at 6.30, George, we said.
column3: Wake us at six point three zero, George, we said.

column2: George made no answer, and we found, on going over, that he had been asleep for some time; so we placed the bath where he could tumble into it on getting out in the morning, and went to bed ourselves.
column3: George made no answer, and we found, on going over, that he had been asleep for some time; so we placed the bath where he could tumble into it on getting out in the morning, and went to bed ourselves.
